Literature Review: Swimming in complex fluids is a fascinating area of research that intersects biology, physics, and engineering. This field has gained significant attention in recent years due to its relevance in understanding microorganism locomotion, designing artificial microswimmers, and developing novel applications in medicine and biotechnology. The study of swimming in complex fluids presents unique challenges and opportunities, as the properties of these fluids can dramatically alter the dynamics and efficiency of swimming mechanisms.Complex fluids encompass a wide range of materials, including polymer solutions, gels, suspensions, and biological fluids such as mucus and blood. These fluids exhibit non-Newtonian behavior, characterized by properties such as viscoelasticity, shear-thinning, and yield stress. The interaction between swimmers and complex fluids can lead to counterintuitive phenomena and unexpected locomotion strategies.One of the key aspects of swimming in complex fluids is the interplay between the swimmer's size and the characteristic length scales of the fluid. Qin et al. (2015) demonstrated that nanoswimmers in viscoelastic fluids can exhibit enhanced propulsion due to the elastic recoil of polymer chains. This finding challenges the conventional wisdom that fluid elasticity always hinders locomotion at small scales.The timescales of fluid relaxation and swimmer motion also play a crucial role in determining swimming behavior. Elfring and Lauga (2015) showed that the swimming speed of a model microorganism in a viscoelastic fluid depends on the Deborah number, which compares the fluid relaxation time to the characteristic time of the swimmer's motion. Their work highlights the importance of considering both spatial and temporal scales when analyzing swimming in complex environments.The presence of boundaries or obstacles can significantly impact swimming dynamics. Mathijssen et al. (2016) investigated the behavior of microswimmers near surfaces and found that hydrodynamic interactions with boundaries can lead to trapping or scattering of swimmers, depending on their shape and propulsion mechanism. This research has implications for understanding biofilm formation and designing microfluidic devices.In addition to physical boundaries, the molecular structure of complex fluids can act as obstacles to locomotion. Martinez et al. (2014) studied the swimming of Escherichia coli in polymer solutions and observed that bacteria can actively modify the fluid microstructure to enhance their motility. This work demonstrates the adaptive nature of biological swimmers and suggests potential strategies for designing artificial swimmers in complex environments.The concentration of swimmers themselves can contribute to the complexity of the fluid environment. Saintillan and Shelley (2013) reviewed the collective dynamics of active suspensions, where the motion of many swimmers leads to large-scale flow patterns and instabilities. These phenomena have implications for understanding the behavior of dense bacterial populations and the design of active materials.Recent advances in experimental techniques have enabled more detailed studies of swimming in complex fluids. Patteson et al. (2015) used particle tracking and rheological measurements to investigate the swimming of Caenorhabditis elegans in viscoelastic fluids. They found that the worms' undulatory motion is enhanced in certain polymer solutions, highlighting the importance of fluid-structure interactions in locomotion.The study of swimming in complex fluids has also inspired the development of novel artificial microswimmers. Huang et al. (2016) designed a magnetically actuated helical microswimmer capable of navigating through viscoelastic fluids. Their work demonstrates the potential for using insights from biological swimmers to create efficient artificial propulsion systems for applications in targeted drug delivery and minimally invasive medical procedures.Understanding swimming in complex fluids has important implications for various biological processes. Celli et al. (2009) studied the motion of human spermatozoa in cervical mucus and found that the rheological properties of the mucus play a crucial role in sperm selection and fertilization. This research highlights the relevance of complex fluid dynamics in reproductive biology and may inform the development of new contraceptive technologies.As the field of swimming in complex fluids continues to evolve, new challenges and opportunities emerge. Future research directions may include investigating the role of active matter in living systems, developing more sophisticated theoretical models to capture the multiscale nature of complex fluids, and exploring the potential of bio-inspired microswimmers for environmental remediation and biomedical applications.In conclusion, the study of swimming in complex fluids represents a rich and diverse field with significant implications for both fundamental science and practical applications. By considering the interplay between swimmer characteristics, fluid properties, and environmental factors, researchers are uncovering new principles of locomotion and pushing the boundaries of our understanding of active matter in complex environments.
